Build enterprise-grade Shiny apps. Best practices included.

Installation 

install.packages("rhino")

Installing from GitHub

To install latest development version or a specific one, run one of the following commands.

# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("Appsilon/rhino")

# Installing rhino either from a specific release or a branch requires providing `ref` argument:
remotes::install_github("Appsilon/rhino", ref = "v0.5.0")

Usage

ğŸ—ï¸ Create a Shiny Application from Scratch

Running rhino::init() will create a following application structure for you. Once that is done simply run shiny::runApp() to start a minimal Rhino application! ğŸš€

With the structure prepared you can configure Rhino or jump straight into development using Rhino!

â™»ï¸ Migrate an Existing Shiny Application to Rhino

To migrate an application to Rhino create an application from scratch as described above. Then refer to rhino::init() details section for a recommended approach of proceeding with the migration.

ğŸ”§ Configure Rhino with rhino.yml

Rhino uses its own rhino.yml config file for preserving your preferences. Currently available options are described in the taxonomy below.

rhino.yml Taxonomy 

sass: string               # required | one of: "node", "r"
legacy_entrypoint: string  # optional | one of: "app_dir", "source", "box_top_level"
sass

Configures whether SASS should be build using R package or Node package. The latter provides newest implementation, at a cost of additional system dependencies for development (node and yarn).

legacy_entrypoint

This setting is useful when migrating an existing Shiny application to Rhino. For more details see rhino::app() details section.

Contributing

Pull requests are welcome! Please see our contributing guidelines for more details.

Tool Command devtools equivalent Comment
Unit tests testthat::test_local() devtools::test()
Linter lintr::lint_package() devtools::lint()
pkgdown site pkgdown::build_site() devtools::build_site() If built successfully, the website will be in docs directory.
